Nice collection. A nice, large collection. I was most interested in the new Indonesian Art, although the collection of Foreign Artists living in Bali was also nice.

Beautiful. This museum has a lot of traditional Balinese art as well as paintings by the Dutch painter, Water Spies and some of his students. It is well laid out, has exhibits ranging from traditional to contemporary, and is easy to get around. One building had an exhibit of old photos donated by a couple who lived on the island in the early 20th Century. The photos are of different ceremonies, dances, etc. Truly spectacular! Don't miss it!

Linda Vall loves painting. First visited the Neka Museum around 14years ago.......could not miss a second visit when we were in Ubud in July2014. The paintings are lovely, and the museum exudes an overall quiet from the hustle and bustle of downtown Ubud.Don't miss it if you are looking for something to do in Ubud.

Small but beautiful museum. Some western museums by their very nature can be dull, 'stuffy' and not particularly inspiring, Neka on the other hand is open, clean, airy and situated in very pleasant gardens. Some great art works there ranging from traditional artworks through to the contemporary: sculpture, wood carvings etc. I particularly enjoyed the photo gallery containing images from the 1930's etc and the large upstairs gallery devoted to the ceremonial dagger, the Kris. This alone is well worth the visit. Entrance fee is 50,000 IDR (at the time of writing less than USA$5) and certainly well worth the money.

A must do in Ubud even if you're remotely interested in art.. This is a superb collection of works in a beautiful setting giving an in depth opportunity to understand the cultural and artistic significance of Ubud. The works exhibited will blow you away!
Goood collection. First museum in Ubud and stedily improving from there. Wide selction of paintings and a kris collection. Great introduction and a good thing to do. Recommended.
Great place. Beautifully set out gallery showcasing the history of Balinese art and well catalogued. Highly recommended to spend a morning or afternoon.

Nice collection and variety. The buildings and grounds of this museum are as nice as the art inside. Great collection of old and new paintings. Set up is a bit strange like benches to rest one that don't face paintings ..or wonderful statues that have something behind the that take away slightly from the piece. Do spend some time in the Classic Balinese section. If you read the descriptions it will tell you a story contained in the picture. I learned quite a bit about the myths and history of this wonderful island.

Really mixed bag. The kris collection was GORGEOUS and really diverse. If you have any interest in ceremonial knives, go and enjoy!The rest of the collection was eclectic and didn't provide any overview or clear timeline of the development of Balinese artistic traditions. It felt very hit or miss.

Good cross section of Balinese art.. This is a great museum of the recent history of Balinese painting. The place could do with some better text on the wall which explains the significance of the artist or the style and how it links to the development of different styles, but I don't think this is in the style of this place. I am amazed by the lack of archival display techniques but it is definitely in the style of the Bali way.
Wonderful site. A must visit, easy walk north from Anini Raka where we stayed, other wise about 30 mins walk from Ubud town.
Extremely good museum. The Neka has an excellent collection of traditional Balinese art. This and the ARMA museum are essential destinations.

Perhaps my expectations were unrealistic. Balinese painting has a very particular style, and I suppose I don't particularly like it. Not that I dislike it or can't appreciate the creativity and composition, use of colour etc, I just find myself getting quite tired and a bit disinterested quite quickly.I also can't help but ponder (this may be my underlying problem) that I am looking at representations of Balinese life as seen (I think exclusively), through the eyes of men, be they locals or visitors, and that not infrequently concern young, semi-naked women. Having said that, I did find a number of extremely painterly works. The gardens are pretty, it's a good place to escape central Ubud, note that the cafe closes early, and it's cool. I'd certainly recommend you visit as the written notes to paintings are informative about Balinese traditions and culture.Only people who want something for nothing would baulk at the 50,000Rp entry fee.

Worth the walk!. Quite the walk to go there but it's worth it! Can't say I'm a big fan of Balinese art (although I love some of the paintings) but it is definitely interesting and the explanations are well doneFun thing was that we went to a Kecak dance the day after and were able to understand most of the story thanks to the explanation panels at the museum!
Exotic place. Not big place, but has quite a collection. Good place to rest and wonder for art lover.We had free tickets from the villa, really clever idea actually

Ok, I'm no art lover so read with a grain of salt.... Neka Art museum is like your typical art museum. It's situated between several buildings across its grounds with each building featuring a different era or type of art. There is no air conditioning in the buildings so if there's no cross breeze, plan for it to be hot.They have a gift shop with your typical Indonesian wares, with ridiculous prices.Our tour package included a visit to Neka which is why we went. If I had to pay, I'm not sure I would have visited.
best painting museum in bali. the museum have large collection for balinese painting, time through time and some art collection beside paintings, worth to visit!
quiet and well laid-out gallery.. Super selection of traditional and modern pieces. Virtually no other visitors. Excellent value. (I intended this review for Neka, not ARMA).

Definitely worth a visit.. If you fancy a bit of culture while in Ubud, this lovely museum, about a 15/20 minute drive from the centre of Ubud, hosts an excellent collection of Balinese paintings, drawings, and sculpture; pieces by contemporary Indonesian artists, and a very interesting photographic archive of Balinese life in the 1930's and 40's - as well as possibly the largest collection of ceremonial daggers (keris) you will ever see. There is a small entrance fee. Take a bottle of drinking water with you, you may need it.
Best Art Gallery. No doubt this is the place to get the best overview of Balinese art in a peaceful, tranquil, we'll kept setting,
Worthwhile visiting. Beautiful collection of Balinese and foreign artists work depicting Balinese life and people. Building and history also interesting
An essential stop if you're in the Ubud area. An incredible museum, which highlights the extensive cultural heritage of Bali - and in a beautiful setting amongst the rice terraces.
Huge Collection. It was a big collection. Not as diverse as Agung Rai. We went because we were staying nearby. I don't think I would go out of my way to visit unless you are a big art lover.
Our favorite museum in Ubud. One of our favorite place in Ubud with a large collection of painting and photos. A very nice place to learn more about Bali history and Balinese custom.
Most interesting. We are not into art to any great extent, but enjoyed the comprehensive display. We were surprised that we filled in two hours without any difficulty

Comprehensive collection of classical and contemporary Balinese Art. Being a collector of Indonesian contemporary art, I have longed admired the unique style, composition of Balinese art and the talented artist who created them. At Neka museum, featuring a comprehensive and nicely curated collection, I was able to appreciate all the beautiful Balinese art by both classical as well as contemporary Balinese artists such as Nyoman Gunasa. What makes Neka special is that you get to admire Balinese art in its original source - Ubud where the artists drew inspiration from over the ages and you get to see the evolution and progression of Balinese art from the traditional composition depicting village ceremony and life in intricate illustrations to the dynamic expressive style of contemporary Balinese artist, expressing the soul and beauty of Ubud, it's spirit , culture , history and heritage in vibrant brush strokes and vivid colors. Certainly a MUST VISIT for lovers of Indonesian and Balinese art.

Balinese art old and new. The price of the entry ticket is far too much but the gallery itself is marvellous. You can wander through the different rooms taking in the old artworks with their unique style and on to modern paintings. It gives you the impression that the natural world, the spiritual world and our human condition are major forces in the minds of the artists. A lovely reflection of Balinese culture.

Interesting assortment of art. Interesting museum showing artwork that probably won't survive very long due to the fact that this place isn't climate controlled. Best to take a long then head across the street to Naughty Nuri's for some great BBQ!

Perfect collection of art and documentary. If you are into art don't miss this museum. There is a vast collection of Neka's paintings. If you are into art don't miss this museum. There is a vast collection of Neka's paintings.
Great afternoon. Neka has a fantastic and interesting collection. A lovely afternoon spent meandering through the many pavilions. Informative and varied collection of artworks; thoroughly enjoyed!

Impressive, well kept museum. Being an artsy fartsy person, I notice that many art galleries in the country is not well taken cared of... except for this one. The collection is impressive, very informative, the English translations actually makes sense, they even have Japanese translations. The art gallery is well put together and categorized. They have Ubud style, Batuan style, Foreign artists and pavilions for specific famous artists such as Lempad Pavilion.It's clean and the merchandise store is filled with great Balinese art books. Well worth a visit!

Informative Gallery. Recommended for people trying to appreciate Balinese culture, not just art lovers. A bit out of town, but a downhill walk back, the collection is very well organized in a series of buildings set in nice grounds. The collection includes photos from the 1930s as well as contemporary art . Well worth an hour or two of your time.

Small museum but very nice. While in Ubud art lovers should stop by this very nice museum. The mix of western and balinese styles of the art collection, the set up of the museum in balinese traditional architecture with its courts, gardens and carved doors, the quietness of the place, all this make your visit to Neka highly enjoyable. It is like having a rest from the crowded and busy city. You are not going to spend three days in it, like you may in le Louvre or in the MET, but the art collection in itself is very interesting and will fill 2 or 3 hours of your life with beauty.
art hunting. Collect art - and having being shown round umpteen galleries with a million masters - this one has the cream of whats on offer.
Arts lovers must see. This collection includes a wonderful combination of both traditional and modern works. The museum is situated in lovely grounds.
Fascinating. Great collection of Balines paintings very well set out in a lovely setting just outside Ubud. Spend about 3 hours to see the lot.
Worth a couple of hours.. If you are interested in art this is a must. The Arie Smidt exhibition is very uplifting. The buildings and grounds are also very peaceful.

It's like visiting a someone's home. Neka Museum is more than a museum. The art pieces are housed in a big old bungalow with beautifully manicure garden, which makes you feel as though you are entering into someone's private home. It has a huge collection of Indonesian paintings that date as far back as 1930s. You get to appreciate the stark difference of Indonesia then and now. We spent an hour there, awed by the intricacies of the paintings and wondering the whole time, how these pieces look so perfect despite been hung so close to the open windows, exposed to the humidity.Note: 3km fm centre of Ubud.Go by taxi,fares are cheap and bargainable.

Great exposition of Balinese art. Having been to most of the other galleries in Ubud I would rate this my favourite (though ARMA is close) because it explains so well the development of Balinese art from the 2 dimensional influence of Javanese puppets to the present.

Interesting art and beautiful grounds. There are probably about 200 pieces in this museum -- not a huge representation of local art. Still the works were very interesting and broadly representative of the short history of Bali art. The grounds are beautifully maintained. I am glad to have seen it. The price was modest.
Good and quiet. Very nice, a moment of escape in a crowded Ubud.Go there if you love paintings. The place is huge, and quiet, and spacy. Nice!
Not As Good As what i Expected. I have a high expectation on Neka Art Musuem before i pay the visit. It is an average art musuem i would say. Nothing much impressed me.
Beautiful Hofker drawings. don't miss them, because they're only in 1 pavilion. Have a look at the historical and comtemporary art from Bali
a must see. This museum should be a must see for all visitors to Ubud. The paintings are incredible and there is a good history of Bali in the artwork.

One of the top 2 Galleries in Ubud. Beautiful setting with wide collection representing all period of Balinese art. I took a few gansa (instrument) lessons with Wayan which was enlightening in learning more about Balinese music.

Neka Art Museum. a significant art museum which presents an historical and artistic perspective of Ubud. The museum is housed in a most impressive a set of interconnected buildings. Needs to be visited!

Good Museum in Ubud. With Blanco Museumn (more for the place and atmosphere), this is my favorite in Bali. Collections are nice and interesting. The museum is quite big. The price is not as ridiculously expensive as in Nusa Dua.

Worth a visit!. The place to go on your first day in Ubud. It will give you an excellent overview of the many styles of Balinese art with representation of most of the islands famous artists. Cool and breezy rooms and a gorgeous garden with resident geese.
A good overview of art history. i liked a good selection of pictures and photos but I missed some statues. A convenient location close to stores and some other galleries.
Time. Make sure you give yourself enough time to view this museum entirely. Since they have huge interesting collections.

An excellent introduction to Balinese art. We wanted to understand the history and influences of Balinese art before making any decisions to purchase and this was the perfect education! Well curated and really interesting. Well worth a look if you are into art.
More than the art.... The art was wonderful, the presentation and the grounds were breathtaking, and the social history told through the paintings was delightful.
A wonderful collection. Simply a wonderful collection of paintings of different style and age from the old to the modern. I have been here several times and never get tried of it! A must in Ubud.
It was ok. The art was cool, some funky modern art as well, didn't expect that. The grounds were a bit smaller than I would have thought, but overall ok.

Excellent museum. The museum and garden are beautiful in themselves. The collection is unsurpassed. The owner has made a point to collect along the range of Balinese art, and it's very good.Once you see this, and then you go to the street-----you'll understand why most of painting be sold on the street is tourist stuff. And you'll be able to spot what might be good.This is a lovely place to spend a few hours.

Fascinating!. Though I am not the biggest fan of art museums, I found the Neka Art Museum very interesting and fascinating. No doubt, the paintings are beautiful but what I enjoyed the most was how the paintings tell you a lot about Balinese culture (and its development over time due to western immigrants), religion, myths and history!
beautiful gardens and lovely displays. An easy place to roam, even in rainy weather. Relaxed environment, pleasant surroundings, beautiful art work. I loved the photos from the twenties.
ok.. We walked all the way from Ubud Center there, but somehow the art wasn't that great. There are many nicer smaller Art Galleries on the way which I suggest to stop by.
Ubud culture. The museum is a beautiful building in itself and has calm attractive gardens, content of the gallery is extremely interesting
Too Many Paintings. There was not much heritage or story connecting the art: too many painting. It was also an expensive entry fee!
Excellent selection of Balinese art. This is a private museum with a very good selection of Balinese paintings displayed in several buildings. The best art museum I have been to in Bali.

See real Balinese art, not just the tourist stuff on Monkey Forest Road in Ubud. If you go to art museums when you visit cities in America or Europe, you absolutely should visit the Neka Art Museum. You will learn a lot about how Balinese see the world. The art there stems from Germans and other Europeans teaching Balinese Western art techniques in the '20s and '30s. Then they took the ball and ran with it. So visiting this museum is both an artistic and a cultural experience. It includes art by Westerners with Balinese subjects.When we went the museum was practically empty expect for us and Russian-American couple we're friends with. This is a serious art museum with worthy art in it, from abstract expressionist works to the most typical Balinese paintings--colorful, crowded depictions of the busy work and social life that's all intertwined for most Balinese. It's a short drive from Ubud, doesn't cost much to visit, and is on attractive grounds. Tourists would do themselves a favor by spending less time at cheesy, tropical-generic tourist attractions and more at uniquely Balinese ones like this. Whatever genre of art you like, from avant garde/ironic to more traditional expressions, it can be found here.

Do not miss it. It is a good museum, especially if you wish to understand the balinese art. It is required to forget about museum in Europe before to enter: in Indonesia and in general in Asia, it is not easy to find a nice place with the passion for Art. And to not miis the Keris part, really beautiful.

Great collection, beautifully housed. The Neka museum is set across 8 different pavilions, some only large room sized, within beautiful lush gardens. The highly polished crimson floor tiles and white walls establish an excellent canvas to display the art. The art is all quite recent, with the earliest coming from the mid 20th century. It covers traditional Balinese painting, highly complex and generally telling stories of every day life or of Hindu legends; modern Balinese painting by indigenous artists; and art by visitors who settled in Bali, mainly Dutch, Australian and Phillippino. The explanations for each picture are comprehensive, and the art is logically arranged by style or artist. 1.5 to 2 hours gives you a comprehensive look. It's a good walk from Ubud Palace if you are fit- otherwise a simple cab fare. After visiting, we were comfortable that the painting we had bought the day before had some grounding in genuine Balinese painting--probably smarter to go to the gallery first though!
wonderful. I liked this museum a lot, there is a great collection of art spread over different buildings.The grounds are beautiful.

Museum with great library of balinese arts and painting. Liked: good library of balinese paintings and art pieces. The museum is well maintained, airy and cleaned. The neka museum is owned by the komaneka resort and komameka guests have free complementary tickets and shuttle to the museum. The best thing is its location because the museum is just opposite the world famous naughty nuri's warung which served great pork ribs Disliked : the souvenir section is not very well maintained , suggestions to the management if they can stocked the souvenir section with more paintings and artifacts for sales.Verdicts: good place to visit in the morning around 1100am, it will take around 1 hour to tour the museum and thus by noon you can pop over to naughty nuri's warung for lunch

the best Museum. Beautifull well kept colonial buildings in a tropical garden (beautifull butterflies and spiders) with a great colection of paintings and sculptures. All in all the most beautifull museum I know!
Great gallery. Beautifully presented gallery specialising in all the schools of Balinese art, including the owner's fine kris collcection. Well woth a visit.

Nice to see. I thought that Neka could have done with a little facelift. Some paintings seemed lost in the building, possibly only because of it's positioning. Still worth a visit, its close to Ubud Centre and not expensive. Amazing original B/W photos from 20/30'S Bali.
You have to love Indonesian art. Beautiful setting with a large collection of Indonesian art. Skip the lunch options and just tour the collection. Better food awaits close by
the best gallery in Ubud. The gallery houses a fine collection of paintings from every school of Balinese art. Highly recommended. Takes about 2 hours to get round.

Terrific art with detailed explanations. I really enjoyed this museum - beautiful Balinese paintings from many time periods, as well as some sculptures and photos. Excellent explanations beside each work really enhanced my experience.

Superb, and don't miss the kris collection. We were attending the Ubud Writers and Readers Festival (5 star!) in October, and one of the main venues was the big pavilion at Neka. So of course we took the opportunity to re-visit an old favourite and were delighted. The setting is as lovely as ever, the whole museum is superbly maintained and the work is beautifully displayed. And a surprise - we were encouraged to visit the newly-opened kris gallery, up the staircase near the reception desk. An extraordinary collectionof these ceremonial knives, with excellent interpretive material and an informative display of how a kris is made, step by step. A great addition to a wonderful art museum.

Great insight into Balinese culture. Take your time walking through here and you will learn much about the island and it's people. It's a wonderful old building full of bright paintings, sculptures and photography and well worth a visit.

Wonderful chance to see Balinese Art. I was in Ubud for an Art Class, so a visit to Neka was a must. This has an excellent collection of local art by both Balinese and foreigners. This is a must for any art lover.

Very interesting. Enjoyed our visit to see traditional and contemporary Balinese art and sculpture. The architecture of the museum and gardens was beautiful.Worth a visit if you like Balinese art and culture.
Step into Bali's history. This should be on your list of places to visit in Ubud and allow at least a hour to see some incredible artwork from local and overseas artists
amazing arts in Bali. How amazing art works and artist in Bali!!! The prints with the tranditional story, can make our know more about this county
Fine Art. The Neka Art Museum is great. It is set in a wonderful area, shows excellent art objects. We loved the huge terrace with the cafeteria for relaxing.

No place to eat. Wonderful art collection if you are seriously into eclectic and enjoy the off-beat. Gives a good sense of Balinese art past and present. Some very creative modern art. But the cafe is a non-starter. Don't count on it for a meal.

Highly Enjoyable. Would definitely recommend this museum and then to also attend at the Neka Gallery as you won't be disappointed with either. We also made some purchases in the museum gift store to be given as gifts; prices were reasonable.

Very interesting. An excellent way of spending an afternoon in Ubud, plenty of interesting stuff, and conveniently placed to finish off the day with a few beers and the best pork ribs in the world across the road at nuri's.

Surprisingly good. Really interesting and complete. It shows all the history of Bali with its tradicional animic rituals and special swords. Photos in black and white depicting the island in the 40s were fantastic, then you could see what was Bali before the mass tourism. Many pictures made by the westerns and natives are awesome as well showing specific details that help us to understand better the traditions of their culture. A must in Ubud. It was empty when i went there by bicycle so i enjoyed more.

Beautiful art and grounds. The Neka art gallery is a wonderfully laid out history of Balinese art. The grounds and buildings are beautiful. Definitely a good place to walk off the ribs and beer from Naughty Nuri's across the road!

Good place to learn about history of Balinese art & culture.. MIt houses many exhibits, mostly paintings from old to contemporary. I like the ones on Hindu mythology , Ramayana. It is a quiet place. Can take your own sweet time to look at the paintings & the captions.
interesting place. we liked it. definitely worth checking out on your way to monkey forest for example...since its located in the same road pretty much

Neka Art Museum. It was a lovely, quiet serene and quite large gallery in the middle of Ubud. I just loved it. It had a large selection and variety of excellent art from many fine Balinese painters ( mainly). Of course the whole building had wonderful carvings which is common to most Balinese buidlings. I would like to have spent more time there and well as other galleries. Ubud is such a busy place that this was a real oasis of genuine Bali with no one trying to sell you anything.
Interestin but expensive. interesting, not too big, with good explanations , but expensive. Worth a visit if you want to see a few pieces of antique balinese paintings ..

If you make only one "cultural visit" make it this one. A quiet and wonderfully curated collection of Indonesian art.
Make sure you leave time to see the photography section which is a great trip into the country's past and culture.

Good museum with explanations on Balinese art periods. Nice museum, similar to the Puri Lakisan Museum. The photography exhibit offeres a nice glimpse into Bali before the intrusion of tourists and heavy western influences. Good explanations about different periods in Balinese art. Also, a small exhibition of I Gusti Nyoman Lempad's work, an internationally known Balinese artist. And another section on contemporary Indonesian artists.
The Best. Many museums that we have visited, Neka museum is one that we admire. You do not forget to visit to this museum if you come to Ubud.

Most interesting museum. This was a well designed and maintained museum with wonderful exhibits of art, woodwork and pottery. I also enjoyed the separate section devoted to the Balinese weapons. The location high up the valley with majestic views was an extra benefit.

A wonderful place to appreciate Ubud Arts. This museum is next door to Uma by COMO, and is said to be the most comprehensive collection of traditional and modern Balinese paintings on the island. Entry costs £4, and the collection includes 6 pavilions covering Balinese painting from the 17th century onwards, as well as European and American artists and photographers who have lived and painted in Bali, and had an influence on local artists. It is well worth an hour's visit. For the full review and images, please visit - www.thelondonfoodie.co.uk

the classic one. Named after a Balinese teacher Suteja Neka who collected paintings as a means of artistic documentation, this museum is unique because its collection of foreign artworks by Balinese, other Indonesian, and foreign artists all were inspired by the natural beauty, life, and culture of Bali.We love this museum because they still keep the classic style of the museum, in here you can see the "Keris" collection, old photography, painting and many more.Suggestion : - After going around in this museum, you can try the restaurant across the road call " naughty nuris " and try the pork ribs, would be delicious.
Good museum and gardens. Excellent museum, and lovely gardens, near the centre of Ubud. A good place to start a trip with an introduction to Balinese culture.

Quiet day at the museum. Very nice to be able to get an overview of the Balienese painture in a setting, enable you to get out every now and then and relax and reflect upon what you have seen. Very nice gardens and I spent an instructive and relaxing afternoon.

A Museum definitely not to be missed!. I was looking forward to visiting the famous Neka Art Museum in Ubud as word has it that they have a fantastic Kris collection (or Keris in Indonesian). The museum also houses art collections from the early classical Balinese paintings to the transitional styles and the Ubud and Butuan style paintings. There’s a section for young artists and contemporary style paintings (which I couldn’t appreciate!) and contemporary Indonesian art, including some black and white photographs. On display are also works by current Indonesian artists and some foreign artists, as long as these have been inspired by the culture, natural beauty and life of Bali in them.We were highly appreciative and humbled that Pak Suteja Neka, the originator, founder and current Director of these precious art and Kris collections offered to show us around and give us a tour of his awesome collection, which originated as a passionate hobby, now is recognized as an institute of international standing. We began with the the amazing kris collection. In 2005, UNESCO declared the Indonesian keris as a great cultural achievement of world humanity. The kris is much more that just a weapon. Each piece has some history and story to tell, has been decisive in winning battles, has given their owner power and strength, and it goes on. Considering the time they were forged, the craftsmanship is utterly amazing and mind boggling, not to mention the inlaid decorative precious jewels and stones, delicate carving, the balance between blade and handle, etc.The art collection comprising over 300 pieces, grouped and classified, is housed in several buildings and rooms, which in themselves have been patterned in Balinese architecture. Much information about early Balinese life and culture can be gleaned from these precious art works. They are so priceless with regards to research, education and information for anyone who’s interested, and an inspiration for non-Balinese visitors. Unfortunately, we didn’t have the luxury of spending much time at this section, but had a overall account with details of certain interesting pieces pointed out to us. It was however, sufficient to have an appreciation of the cultural and life style changes that transited over the years in Bali through the eyes of various artists!You can spend an entire day if you’re so inclined, to look closely at the collection, or you can browse them in the groups that they are shown without getting into small details, and still appreciate the changes or transition in the culture, life, and the natural beauty of early and contemporary Bali.Whatever you choose to do in Ubud, don’t pass up the chance to visit this awesome museum. It’s not to be missed. And it’s definitely worth a return visit!Neka Art MuseumRaya Campuhan St.Kedewatan Village, Ubud Gianyar 80571The Museum is opened :Monday-Saturday: 9 A.M.- 5 P.M.  Sunday: NOON - 5 P.M.  Closed: National Holiday.ADMISSION FEE  for the Permanent Collection. Rp. 50.000 Adults and Free for children 12 and under.

A must for those who are interested in Balinese culture and history. this visit needs a minimum of 2hrs time as one should visit the pavilions according to the history of painters living in Ubud - since a century and more.

Balinese art also collection of kris daggers. Even if you don't much care about art, it's worth coming here just to see the fine collection of keris (or kris) daggers, with jeweled hilts and curved blades. The best such collection I've seen. They are, however, all behind glass which makes them difficult to photograph. This collection is on the second floor, and you may have to ask someone how to find it. Plenty of paintings and statues, representative of several different genres and styles. Some old and some new. A very fine place, overall.

Visit this Museum when in Ubud. Our driver from Samaya Ubud suggested we spend an hour here. And true enough, we completed most of what we wanted to see in an hour. We enjoyed our visit. Even my young children seemed to have a good time. For those with young children, watch out for some dangerous and very low windows on the second floor of some of the buildings. The management should put in some safety grills on those.Aside from traditional Balinese paintings, we found many contemporary styled paintings and interesting sculptures. I particularly liked Arie Smit's works. I also found a room full of old photographs of Balinese life which were interesting.The interiors of the buildings are not very posh and lack airconditioning that most modern galleries have for preservation of the art work. I wonder how the Museum keeps the paintings in good condition. The grounds are nice with some ducks on the lawn and people playing Indonesian instruments in one pavillion.It's a pleasant place to spend an hour in the afternoon when it's too hot to do much else.
Worth seeing. We were really impressed with a great Bali art collection in a beautiful setting. It is really worth visiting.We highly recommend going there and spending some time.

Best collection of Balinese art. This museum has a well laid out and well explained collection of Balinese art, including old temple paintings. The gift shop is excellent and has beautiful local craft items for sale.

Good Bali Museum. Good museum but not the best. Kinda out of the way to get to. If you need to kill a few hrs and have nothing else to do its worth it... But if you don't have the time ur not missing much.
Beautiful collection.. Great painting collection. Clear explanation, it world class museum. Don't forget to add this place when you're goin to trip to Ubud. Great experience.

nice to visit. A great place to learn more about the work of the bali. Many painting are on display in this museum, there are a few of the many who have reached age decades. It is remarkable the work of people in Bali, especially in Ubud town.

Worthwhile to appreciate the evolution of art in Ubud. The exhibitions have some really good explanations of the different art styles and the evolution of the styles and techniques over the years, from original traditional styles to modern day. The exhibition using incomplete paintings to illustrate the techniques used in traditional Ubud style paintings was illuminating. There are also detailed explanations of the significance of certain images or icons in Balinese traditions (i now understand what carvings and statues of horses are so popular! I loved the photos from the 1940s. Best of all was having the opportunity to learn about the art without any pressure to buy! I came away with a much better understanding of what I was looking at in the shops, and a real appreciation for the amount of time and effort that goes into some of the works.

Good for the art lover to see a historical development. This private museum is layer out with a clear historical development in Balinese art. The influences of European art can clearly be identified as you wonder thought he various buildings. A very nice selection of key contributors and a diverse range of stylistic approaches throughout the 70-90's. the collection really is just a lot of works hanging on the walls with a sense of lack of preservation beginning to prevail. The Arie Smit works are particularly of interest.

Small museum with a few interesting wood sculptures. By world-class standard, this is a tiny museum. I am not interested in paintings in general and have nothing to say about that. But it does have a few some museum-quality wood sculptures. For a place that is known for producing world-class wood sculptures, it is a puzzle why there is not a museum with a huge collection of wood sculptures. A master sculptor in Ubud even claimed that there is no such museum in the whole Indonesia. The master sculptors are wasting their talents in Indonesia?
Diamond of Ubud. If you want to get into the heart of Ubud's art, this is the place you must visit. Every pieces and every details are marvelous. Don't miss this love art museum.
good paintings. A lot of beautiful paintings by Balinese painters.A must see!The pavilions were artfully decorated. One pavilion is contributed to a Dutch painter Arie Smit.

Must to Visit. Museum one of the many museums in Ubud. Nice place, we can learn how to draw people Bali story taken from about Hindu culture. Each image has its own meaning and many styles we can see, there is traditional or modern style.
Learn about Balinese art culture. Modern to older traditional paintings and a little history of Bali, a good way to get an overview and understanding of Balinese culture.
Great art museum. Huge art museum a bit out of town but worth the trek if you're an art lover. Good variety of art spans through a few different buildings.

This is a good place to start if you're thinking about buying art in Ubud. This is a lovely museum and I enjoyed it entirely. There was good history and a fine display of Balinese art from several eras. I wish the gift shop had more choice and better quality prints for sale.

Cool museum. large open air museum with cool collection of paintings and wood craves.displaying artworks of famous artist both traditional and contemporary, I really enjoyed this museum and recommend it to everyone who will visit Ubud.

Worth visiting for the many masterpieces in the museum. Initially, I was hesitant about visiting the museum. There are many free art galleries in the same area and this museum charges an entry fee of 50,000 IDR. Moreover, I find going to a lot of small local museums a let down after having been to the top museums in Paris, Florence, Vienna, Zurich etc. It doesn't help that I also don't like the dark palettes of traditional Indonesian paintings. Despite all these misgivings, I still went. Boy, am I glad I did! I was stunned by the masterpieces by artists like Affandi, Arie Smit, Walter Spies, Dullah, J. Elizalde Navarro, I. Walter Pasti et al. This museum is stock full of canvases to delight the senses with colour, energy and and an almost uncanny life-like expressiveness. If you only want to visit ONE museum in Bali, make it this one.

Wow, take the time to visit Neka. This museum is a bit out of the way from downtown Ubud, but was worth the taxi ride. It's a large, open air museum made up of many different buildings and works of art including a balinese paining area, Indonesian contemporary artists, puppets, and an area for Gusti Nyoman Lempad. I was truly amazed by the collection and felt the entrance fees was undervalued at $5 US. The gift shop was a great stop if you didn't buy any sarongs in the market. They were exquisite here.
Must see. Lovely shop with fine quality Balinese crafts, Museum has extensive collection of traditional and contemporary art, beautiful, quiet gardens.

Best in Indonesia. The Neka Museum is one of the best in Indonesia. It is housed in a series of charming Balinese buildings with lovely gardens populated by ducks and birds. The collection show the evolution of Balinese art from traditional to contemporary with a scattering of expat artists who changed modern art in Indonesia. A great 2 hour visit.

Great Place. Good place to learn about balinese paintings and keris, good place to hang out... the price is worth the view... Friendly staff great collection.... a must see...!!! Been there several times with friends and collegues

Comprehensive, well organized collection- a delightful education.. This large museum, while not as beautifully situated or centrally located as the Museum Puri Lukisan, nonetheless has an unparalleled, extensive collection of painting, sculpture and carving the reflects the evolution of Balinese art. The museum's founder was the son of a carver famous in the 60"s; the depth of the collection reflects their friendships with the major luminaries on the Balinese art scene.There paintings are grouped by styles, with explanations of the evolution and differentiating features of each described. Not all the paintings are attributed, but until western influence, Balinese artists didn't usually sign their work, so some of the minimalist signage is to be forgiven. Sculptures are scattered throughout. There is a nice range and depth to the works, even the more contemporary pieces. Exclusive to this museum is a huge collection of Kris, or Balinese daggers, many prize winning from contemporary competitions. Mokume-gane blades, golden, ivory and wooden handles and sheaths, gemstone encrusted Ganesha's- even if you do not like weaponry (me!), the beauty of some of these pieces is not to be denied. (Always pains me to see the artistry that we invest in weapons, however there is ritual religious significance to the Kris, which may be why such beauty is invested in its creation.)Gift shop with books and prints of selected work on site.

Neka Art Museum. This is a wonderful display of Balinese art. They have a numb of galleries displaying a range of work. I was particularly blown away as they say by the work of one of Bali's famous woodcarvers whose name I have of course forgotten. Look out for the carving of the prone deer with her young one sheltering behind her- it was so evocative that I felt quite weepy.They have the usual museum facilities with the bonus of a pleasant view over the gorge
Art gallery a highlight.. Gives an insight into the culture of Bali in the last century and the power of one artist to fire up an arts community. Beautiful work.

Great Museum. Brought Indonesian art, both traditional and contempory to life and gave real meaning to it. Some amazing pieces to see. Definately one of my favourite museums. Can highly recommend a couple of hours here.

Thoroughly enjoyable. Wonderful setting. I loved learning about Arie Smit (a Dutchman) who settled in Bali and helped young Balinese artists express their painting in a more contemporary style.An interesting photography section depicting Balinese life before many Westerners travelled there.Definitely recommended.

Wonderful museum. I really enjoyed this museum and highly recommend it to everyone, who is interested in Balinese culture. There are a lot of famous paintings, which reproductions you can see all over Bali. The museum is quite large, so plan on spending at least 2 hours there.
Mostly for art buffs. Very good if you are extremely interested in Balinese culture and art. If not you will probably find it a bit boring, there is little here to blow your mind or provoke you.

Great overview of Balinese Art and Large Kris Collection. The layout of the art has a chronological taste of all the major historical Balinese artists and artists who were inspired by Bali. Historical photographs were in a separate bungalow. The Kris collection is amazing, but some of the information is vague.

Not only Art they also have "Kriss" balinese dagger collection. The museum organized very well and profesional, it s good place to know how art improved..
Collection of aold artisant until young artis..

Very nice gallery in beautiful property. We visited the gallery yesterday and loved the house it is based in and the gallery. The pictures are spread over a few pavilions and we particularly liked the ones with contemporary Balinese art and photos. Very easy to navigate and front desk are very helpful. Also has a nice shop at he end of the tour. Would highly recommend a visit.

One of the biggest in Ubud. I actually did not really plan to visit this place, it was unplanned but I kinda like it. It's nice to see something different and actually I they have so many things to see and I never thought about it before..I got a lot of informaton about art and history which is actually very nice to know :)

Nice collection. A nice collection of art from the past and present, nice grounds, good for a visit- please take down the endless pictures, rooms full, of the owner, Mr. Neka, not artistic but narcissistic, nice man but less is really more

Beautiful art and paintings. We had the opportunity here to admire a wide choice of skilled realistic, figurative and asbtact local painters. We were highly surprised by the harmony, textures and interesting compositions from these fine local artists. This museum and others are a must to anyone visiting Ubud.

Surprisingly good.. It's a short list, but the Neka Art Museum is probably *the* museum to visit in Ubud. (Avoid the Rudana - like the plague.) First, the pros: the curation. Here, the history of Balinese painting - from the traditional wayang/Kamasan style, to the works of the so-called transitional era, to the prolific Ubud and Batuan schools of more recent years - is laid out chronologically in separate galleries, with explanatory labels in English, for both broad thematics and individual pieces. The walkthrough ends with several rooms of contemporary Balinese art, which runs the gamut from gestural canvases to abstract sculpture to the local Young Artists movement of the 1960s and '70s. There are also galleries dedicated to specific artists, the most prominent of which is probably Arie Smit, whose work fills an entire floor. (Anyplace else and Smit's brand of recycled Primitivism-meets-Impressionism-meets-Cloisonisme would look embarrassingly vapid - he was painting this stuff even into the '80s and beyond - but here he's a force to be reckoned with. God help the Balinese.) The Lempad gallery, on the other hand, while far more modest in scope, is a revelation. The small drawings which the master has become known for are both aesthetically unique (insofar as Balinese art history is concerned) and fascinating social documents, providing quirky, humour-laced insights into the everyday life of the island in the first half of the 20th century. In short, while the collection may seem a little uneven, the curation - of a surprisingly high standard for an institution of its kind, i.e. a provincial Indonesian museum - deserves a shoutout. Now, the cons: It's a bit of a trek from downtown Ubud. Unless you have transportation, hoofing it over may not be a good idea ... The lack of air-conditioning is also something of a distraction (although, to be here, most other museums hereabouts suffer similar issues). Otherwise, two thumbs up.
Nice Location. I liked that you could just walk in and stroll around the museum.I was told that it was the best art museum in town but I didn't have the same impression.

Had the whole place to myself. This is a good museum and it's not that big so it is not a huge time commitment. The collections are separated into different buildings and it is laid out to move you through time. The building is also worth a look.

An Important Collection. The Neka Art Gallery is set in a series of pavilions in a large garden compound. Each pavilion has a different theme showcasing different styles of art produced in Bali. There is traditional balinese art from several different "schools" based in different villages, the beginnings of western influence on Balinese artists, the work of some influential foreign artists who lived in bali, some fascinating photography, and a collection of contemporary art. Some of the works are wonderful, some less pleasing perhaps, but there is great importance in having a collection like this which reflects themes and developments and trends in the history of art in Bali. This is a most important cultural collection and should not be missed by anyone who has an interest in visual art

Fantastic museum. They have a huge number of beautiful traditional daggers called kris. Interesting black and white pictures of Bali in the 1930s as well as beautiful oil paintings of Bali life. The museum is housed in several small buildings linked by paths through gardens. Worth a look.

Wonderful museum and grounds!. I ended up walking all the way there from central Ubud because I did not realize how far it was. I would not recommend doing that!
Beautiful grounds and buildings. It was most enjoyable and the art works were very interesting and diverse.
absolutely worth a visit. A lovely mix of Asian and western art, set in pleasant gardens, a place for quiet contemplation and the appreciation of Bali's artistic heritage.
Great Indonesian Art. This is probably the best art museum in the Ubud area, and includes artists from various parts of Indonesia

First introduction to Balinese art. Visiting this Museum is between the 2-3 first things that any visitor should do in Ubud - if there is any cultural aim in his/her visit.In the Neka museum you can see paintings, sculptures and photos of the traditional Balinese life and art. Most of the paintings are from XX century (not very old). It was during this century when Ubud became the cultural hub of the Balinese life, and many artists flourished there.And after visiting the full musem, nothing better than crossing the street and go directly the Putri Bali Spa for getting a good foot massage!!

Worthwhile visit. This is a great visit to get a feel for the local art scene. If you stay at any of the Komaneka hotels you can get a free pass. Even so, I would pay to go as it's really interesting.
Interesting Varied Collection. There was a wide variety of art at this museum. I especially loved some of the more contemporary wood carvings and the pictures by Arty Smit.

Museum Neka, if you are interested in beautiful paintings.. Museum Neka has beautiful paintings. I liked the paintings of Bonnet very much. Outside there is a nice view over the valley. A good place to spend some time.

Cultural Oasis. This collection of paintings, sculptures, carvings and photographs is fascinating and enjoyable. The items on show are outstanding and must be amongst the best on Bali. The exhibits are well laid out and labelling is quite informative as well. There were only a handful of other people there which made for a very relaxed two or three hours. The surroundings are beautiful - typically Balinese.There is the usual souvenir shop - though we found this one worth a look. We were a bit disappointed with the cafe offering - though the view was great.Highly recommended for anyone interested in Balinese art and culture.

Great collection in beautiful surrounds. Lovely to escape the heat and stroll through the cool & quiet rooms of this gallery. The collection is well spread out and offers a wide variety of locally produced art from reknown Balinese & foreign Artists. Enjoy the calm as you stroll through & choose your favourite artist. Lovely garden setting.

Great Art museum, Old to contemporary Art!. You probably will take time to look around this museum at least an hour and if you are interested in Art, more than 2 Hours! this is great balinese art museum. Please try.
Good place to visit again. You can see various paintings here. If you aren't interested the painting, you still feel calm and comfortable atmosphere here even if just walking this museum Neka.

see of arts at ubud. neka art museum is at sangingan roads,front of nuris warung the entry gate to this museum .if you want to see the art ,more better visting this place and nice of collection inside .
CULTURE AND A CUPPA. The museum's fabulous as a place to view and experience Balinese artistic expression. The restaurant's great for lunch or dinner ... or just for a coffee.
Wonderful!. Amazing collection of art, beautiful grounds, much better than the gaudy museum down the road! Definitely visit!

To be seen. This is the perfect place one needs to go when experiencing Bali. It's lovely, informative, good for you, does not feel too educational or too institutional. The outdoor spaces are soothing. It's designed very much in the Bali spirit and makes for a wonderful afternoon or early morning.

Excellent collection or art in nice surroundings. We cycled up from Ubud town centre - a bit uphill but not too bad! The museum is reputed to have the best examples of Balinese art and didn't disappoint. We saw a wide variety of traditional paintings - many based on the aesthetic style of old puppet shows - through to those of the Ubud School depicting everyday life, and contemporary artists doing more abstract work. The Arie Smit collection was lovely too. Interesting sculpture as well, both traditional and modern. The setting itself was peaceful, set out among a quiet compound of gardens and pavillions. It was good to absorb something really Balinese, away from the tourist-centric Ubud town centre. Definitely worth a visit.
Best art gallery in Ubud. Very well laid out. Nice cool buildings. Good descriptions. Spend 2 or 3 hours there and don't miss the photographs.

Art Historical. a good overview of the development of art in Bali, so you leave w/ a historical overview of the development, esp. of painting, on the island. The KRIS collection is amazing, and I didn't think I would care much for just looking at "knives", ceremonial or otherwise, but these are fascinating and beautiful.

Excellent Balinese Art Museum. I don't know why there aren't any other reviews for this place. I think it is by far the best art museum in Ubud, perhaps Bali, but I can't really vouch for that. This is a delightful place to spend an hour or two.

Great!. Very interesting collection of Balinese work. It gives the visitor a wonderful overview of modern and traditional work. Bali is over 80 percent Hindu and in the museum it explains how their art and religion is completely intertwined and one cannot be without the other. We loved it. One and a half hours is probably all you need to fully enjoy it.

Lovely art museum: a FANTASTIC collection of keris!. A friend and I enjoyed our visit to this museum: I hadn't known of its existence before our driver Kadek told us about it, or I would have checked it out sooner.The photos and paintings are very interesting and informative. I enjoyed the whole place, but the special display upstairs of the traditional weapons, the kris/keris, was just mind blowing. Anyone who has an interest in knives, swords, damascene steel and the like would be riveted.It is astounding how many different named patterns of damascening can be found on just one blade- my favourite had five separate patterns on a blade that can't have been more than 30cm long.The displays were fascinating, the surroundings were quite beautiful and tranquil. Not a place for little kids, or people with mobility problems, as there are a lot of changes in level. Certainly not what a lot of people would regard as entertaining, but if you are interested in the history and aesthetics of Bali, I would say it is a must, along with the Puri Lukisan museum and the puppet museum, both of which are also in Ubud.
MIND BLOWING. A marvellous insight into the non-tourist Ubud. One of the best museums I have encountered in my many travels around the world

A little dull compared to the other options in Bali. We visited Neka free of charge, as we were provided with entrance tickets through our hotel (Komaneka). Although some of the paintings were interesting, we were a little bored during the visit. We had planned to spend a few hours here, but were done in about 45 minutes/1 hour.
Interesting Museum. Very tranquil and beautiful buildings within glorious tropical gardens with such an interesting mix of art of the different periods in the history of Bali.

Mix of contemporary and traditional art. We loved the contemporary art at the Neka. The Museum is set in lovely grounds and is a good place to explore and get a feel for Balinese culture, through art.
A must. The art work here is amazing and beautifully presented, we are so glad to have made the effort to go. We even met Mr. Neka.

Immerse yourself. This is simply brilliant. For a taste of historic and contemporary art and culture, this is a must-see. Artistic, sensitive, well-balanced, insightful, I could go on... but if you are interested in Balinese sensibilities, this is a do not miss 1/2 day

Great Collection of Keris. I loved the collection of keris, and fortunately had the assistance of an Indonesian gentleman who helped me with the relevant stories associated with that instrument. This art museum is very different to Museum Pasifika in Nusa Dua. For art lovers and/or people who appreciate Balinese culture, both museums are a "must see".
Cultural History. I loved the detailed explanations of the art- it really illuminated the culture. The vintage photography room from the 40s was my favorite. Amazing to see how little has changed!
History in Ubud.. A most interesting museum, beautiful buildings and history.

Balinese art. Neka gallery has a wide range of paintings from and about Bali - local artists and foreign artists who have influenced local art. It's comprehensive and has some truly beautiful stuff. It's also a beautiful place. Really worth a visit.
Time well spent.. 80 years of Bali art, much of it from Ubud. Allow plenty of time. I had 2 hours and it wasn't near enough. Had to go back the next day.

Need more time. We had 2 plus hrs to kill and we did not manage to see all the galleries! Such beautiful artwork on display! They depict the religious, cultural and even political aspects of bali life that we visitors take for granted! It was made even more enriching especially after we watched the evening dance performances! It made us appreciate some of the artwork even more! Although there were some recurring themes, the different artists had different interpretations which made it very interesting! In addition, the fact that it was not like a typical musuem (without the airconditioning and typical museum lights) created a unique experience for us! Highly recommended for avid cultural enthusiasts but do some prior reading/performance watching for further value add!!

Neka Art Gallery: Important Venue for Indonesian Art. The Neka Art Museum is one of Bali’s most important venues for Indonesian art and art by international artists focussing on Bali. This place has several pavilions of paintings and some sculpture, most depicting village life and the everyday rituals and mythology of Bali. Traditional Balinese painting, like Buddhist and Hindu art I’m familiar with, is highly detailed, colourful, and representational, sometimes in a deliberately naïve style. Some of the contemporary Indonesian painting on view looked much like western painting from the 50s, some was reminiscent of German expressionism, and some more like Gauguin. [We were staying in the rice fields and, walking down the street towards the Neka, were also able to visit several contemporary art galleries and studios, the most interesting of which was the Sika Gallery of Contemporary Art.] Entrance to the Museum is 50,000 rupiah (about $5.50).After immersing ourselves in art, we felt a powerful hunger coming on and staggered out of the Neka and into Naughty Nuri’s barbeque house just across the street, where we munched on BBQ’d chicken and pork, along with several other art lovers. Both places are highly recommended. See more info and pictures here: http://lmaclean.ca/2011/10/ubud-art-music-and-dance/

Beautiful museum. The grounds are lovely and the art is thoughtfully and well displayed. The wall signage is excellent and the explanations help in understanding the history of the art. It should not be missed.
Nice collection. a very nice collection, especially the traditional paintings!

Biggest art museum in Ubud.. Many buildings housing art from different Balinese eras. Most are more modern. Also statuary and carvings. This is my favorite museum in Ubud. Allow several hours to see it all.
worth a visit. Good selection of classical Balinese style paintings, with good explanations, as well as more modern work. Very impressive exhibit of kerises with good interpretation.
Great gallery. I think this is the best gallery in Ubud. Well laid out.

Visual wonderland. Excellent Balinese art - very well curated in several buildings set in a superb, terraced garden. Great value including a welcome icy drink at cafe before leaving. A calming but energising place.
Excursion. Well worth a visit - beautiful buildings and very interesting exhibits

Beautiful setting in lush gardens. In the middle of almost nowhere in Ubud, Bali, is this large art gallery which shows off local (and imported) talent. A walk through in about an hour will give one a very good appreciation of the beautiful artwork from local artists. I suggest you visit numerous top quality galleries after your visit to Neka - not before.

Must see art from Tempo Doeloe to now and do not forget to visit the KRIS-department. Beautiful paintings of Bali from the past and present. Inspiring pictures, paintings and a beautiful kris-collection.

Good introduction to balinese arts. There are a ton of different art alleries, art museums etc. in Ubud.But this is clearly the best one to get an overview of the development of paintingstyles in course of time in Bali. Also, the building and surroundings are quite nice.The museum is a bit far out of central Ubud, but I'd still recommend all Ubud visitors to go there, if they have the slightest interest in local arts.
Good collection. Good collection, in hot mornings and afternoon, it is better to call a taxi to go there even you are in the center of Ubud.
Good way to get a quick overview of Balinese art. I liked the contemporary art and Arie Smit rooms the best.

Great for a morning's outing. Took the kids here, there was just enough to look at without them getting bored and annoying. Lots of historical paintings, sculptures and a substantial weapons collection. Excellent view from the restaurant veranda over ravines and rice fields. Worth a look.

Worth a visit. We found this visit very interesting. It was great to see the introduction of many different styles to Bali over the years. We even met Mr Neka who started the museum many years ago. He is a very interesting man.

Very peaceful. This museum was quite interesting, such a contrast of art styles to look at. The gardens and surrounding grounds were beautiful. We received free passes from our hotel, nice way to spend an hour.

Too much to see in just one visit. Anyone with even a passing interest in Balinese art will find much to engage them in the extensive collection of traditional and contemporary art. Set in beautiful grounds, the Museum is organised in pavilions. I was particularly taken with the Batuan style, with intricate and humorous paintings that warrant many viewings. They have so much detail and wit that they are reminiscent of the best graphic novel art of the West. Give yourself plenty of time. The art of many of the Western artists who made their home in Bali is also on display. The Rp 50000 admission is well worth it.
For Ubud, a first choice. For the rest of the world, a good collection in an interesting building. In Ubud, it's probably the best thing in town. If you're in Ubud, visit this spot.

Great Overview of Balinese Art. A comprehensive collection of art that covers a lot of ground. There is plenty of commentary in English and Japanese to explain the works and help viewers understand their significance. I think this museum offers much better value, at the same price, than Pura Lukisan.

worth a visit for the architecture alone!. this gallery has a great selection of balinese art & also a room of arie smit who is a dutch man who has spent his life in bali. his work reflects the daily life perfectly! he has a great passion for the people which shows in his paintings! enjoy! also across from naughty nuris!
Best Art in Bali.. Beautiful grounds and buildings filled with outstanding Balinese art.
Neka Neka. If you are in Ubud don't miss this place's collections, WoW!
What a gem!. This place has them most amazing collection of Keris (swords) and other art. I spent a couple of hours here and loved it.

Balinese art at its best. A comprehensive survey of Balinese art with useful explanatory captions. The buldings and grounds are delightful in themselves. Free entrance (and shuttle service) if you're staying at any of the Komaneka hotels.
Outstanding. Great place to gain an understanding of Balinese painting
museum. Very nice museum and there are always some dance group doing some balinese dance loved it.

The real history of arts and dance in Bali. Black and white photos as well as genuine paintings tell the story of how Bali's art and dance left the sacred space of temples and was made public - it is a great museum in a beautiful compound.

Lovely Museum. A great way to spend an hour in Ubud. I only wish that the traditional art section had matched the modern art section in scope, but never mind. And its a great excuse to stop in at Naughty Nouries across the road for the best BBQ in Ubud.
Fantastic, really requires more than one visit. There is so much here to see and take in. Excellent window on the varieties and depth of Ubud art.
easy walk through. good collection but one of many others in Ubud. the gallery in Tepi Sawah was equally good.

Art at it's best. The Museum was very interesting a great opportunity to see how Indonesian art had changed over timeI am always amazed at many of the paintings there is so much detail in them it would be interesting to know just how long it took the artist to paint the many figures shown in much of the work The museum is so much more professional than some of the quick art done and turned out in the galleries around the shopping areas in Ubud

Large collection of paintings and other art works and well presented.. I spent an hour or two at the Neka Museum on a rainy day in December. There are a collection of buildings with some two stories and you will see everything by following the signs. I found the photographs most interesting and apart from the paintings there were some impressive wood carvings. There is also an impressive collection of keris upstairs in the main building.

Always great as Theresia are some good indonesian painters to see. Do go as it is worth to see. It will take you an hour of two max And in front you can have one of the best luches. Spareribs excellent. Good walk from THE center of ubud
worth a look. Its an icon in the area for those interested in art. That said, its not a wonderful collection, but rather a collection of works of artists that were most likely handled by the owner.
Enjoyed. Did this as it was raining and was worth it - some lovely art work and surrounds.
Balinese Art Overview. Fantastic place to get a solid overview of Balinese painting and sculpture. Best gallery in Ubud.
A Huge Collection of Balinese Works. For a very small fee, you get to see a large collection of Balinese works. You get a sense of how the art had evolved over the years.
Indonesian art in a beautiful building , with superb garden surrounds. Saw early artworks through to modern indonesian art.
See the museums in Ubud!. Neka and other main museums (there are 3 all together) are small but very interesting. Make the time to see them.
worth a visit. some great art that gives a feeling of the island.

A good place to start. Ubud is also famous for its painting and sculpture art and this is the place where you can see how art in Bali evolved from time to time. if you love art, then this place is a must visit site.

The most comprehensive Museum in ubud. I think museum neka has the most variety Collection of fine arts. You can see the evolution of art in Bali from the very old crafts to contemporary paintings from local and international artists

i love the NEKA gallery. this is my favorite art museum in Ubud. I like the grounds and usually if you go in the morning you will have all the airy rooms to view yourself. Really enjoyed all on view by painter Arie Smit, and overall a great collection of paintings in the museum, spanning the history of Balinese art. Excellent photography exhibit as well. Grab a drink and relax on the pretty veranda before heading out.
Good impression of Balinese art. Very nice museum with several beautiful works of art. Gives you a very good impression of Balinese paitinn and sculpture.
Bright colours. The paintings show the life and colourfulness of the people of Bali

Magnificent overview of Balinese art + expat painters and their influence. Great introduction to Balinese art - with very helpful descriptions. Excellent selection of paintings, beautifully displayed. Pavilions are also devoted to various ex-pat painters, including Arie Smit and Donald Friend. We spent over 3 hours there - a very enjoyable visit. This is devoted to displaying a comprehensive selection of paintings in a permanent exhibition - it is not a gallery devoted to sales. so one can enjoy the art without hassle. I suspect going early in the day was a plus - in that we did have the place very much to ourselves!
Just great - a must do. Do not hesitate. Just go. You will probably spend more time than planned. Great overview of Balinese art with some masterpieces. Wonderful atmosphere.

Extensive collection of modern Balinese artists. They gave an extensive collection of Balinese art with among others a large amount of the important works of Arie Smit. Former Dutchman who fell in love with Bali.
We spend almost 3 hours in the museum strolling through the different galleries. This museum was better than the ARMA.

perfect overview. perfect overview of balines paintings,
clean, good light, no guards, only a few tourists
enough info on the walls
nice environment
you can combine this with visiting a few art shops in the street

Excellent Introduction to Local Art and Art History. After reading about the various museums of art in Bali, this was the one that stood out to me as being the most interesting, and I wasn't disappointed. The Neka Art Museum isn't large (and doesn't appear to be at all handicapped accessible, just as a heads-up) but it is well laid out and very pleasant. While it was a little bizarre to wander around a museum whose "climate control" was open windows and verandas, it did make for a pleasant experience. The art was laid out roughly chronologically, with the first halls introducing the older styles of art, then showing how the art started to change and how that change was localized to different parts of the island. The last rooms showed an array of modern Balinese art, and also art done by foreigners who had come to Bali.If you have any interest in art and want a flavor of what the local art scene has been like for the last 150 years or so, this museum is well worth the visit.

Wonderful, wonderful art museum in Ubud. I visited the Museum Puri Lukisan and the Agung Rai Museum of Art (ARMA) which were both very worthwhile, but Neka Art Museum was the last thing I did in Ubud and I loved this one the most. It is open daily from 9am to 5pm and the cost is Rs50,000. It is located just a couple of kms out of town on Jalan Raya Sanggingan. If you are walking, just follow the main street towards Campuan, cross the bridge, walk up the hill and keep going until Neka appears on your right.Give yourself plenty of time as this is a wonderful and extensive collection. There is traditional Balinese work, Balinese and other Indonesian contemporary art, entire pavilions devoted to Arie Smit and I Gusti Nyoman Lempad, extensive displays of artists from abroad who painted in Bali and much more. I really enjoyed Abdul Aziz, Johan Rudolf Bonnet, Willem Gerard Hofker and Donald Friend and many, many others.The pictures are well labeled and well exhibited. This is an excellent collection.
